titlestmt.titleproper: Finding aid for the Henry Goodman collection of theater playbills LSC.2286
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Jenifer Becker with assistance from Julie Graham, March 2016; machine-readable finding aid created by Caroline Cubé.

p.date: Finding aid last modified on 28 April 2016.

address.addressline: Room A1713, Charles E. Young Research Library

publicationstmt.p: This record is made available under an Universal 1.0 Public Domain Dedication Creative Commons license.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-06-27 15:04:00 -0700.

did.unittitle: Henry Goodman collection of theater playbills

physdesc.extent: (1 small flat box, 4 flat boxes, and 3 oversized flat boxes)

did.unitdate: circa 1762 – circa early-1900s, 1951; bulk dates, circa 1830s- circa 1865
did.abstract: Henry Goodman, Ph.D., faculty emeritus at UCLA, had distinguished career as professor of theater. The collection, assembled by Goodman, consists of 18th, 19th, and 20th century British theatre playbills, a small number of American and foreign language playbills, five scrapbooks and a small amount of illustrations.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: Property rights to the objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Henry Goodman Collection of Theater Playbills (Collection 2286). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Problematic Content and Description in UCLA's Library Collections and Archives.

bioghist.head: Biography/History
bioghist.p: Henry Goodman was born November 21, 1919 in Minneapolis, Minnesota. Goodman received his BA (1941), MA (1947), and Ph.D. (1952) from the University of Minnesota. From 1953-1956, he taught at Rockford College in Illinois and at Reed College in Oregon. In 1957, Goodman joined the faculty at University of California, Los Angeles, where he taught and directed until his retirement in 1990. Among his many accomplishments, he introduced and directed the world premiere of Bertolt Brecht's The Caucasian Chalk Circle at Carleton College. Henry Goodman died April 15, 2012 in Los Angeles, California.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of 18th, 19th, and 20th theater playbills and ephemera collected by UCLA professor of theater Henry Goodman. The bulk of the collection are British theater playbills from the 19th century and include specimens from Astley's Royal Amphitheatre; Lyceum Theatre; Nottingham Empire; Royal Princess's Theater; Surrey Theatre; Theatre Royal, Covent-Garden; Theatre Royal, Drury Lane; and others. Additionally, there are a very small number of American and foreign language playbills. Also included are five scrapbooks representing 19th and early 20th century theatre.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p:
The collection is organized in the following series:
1. Theatre Playbills
2. Scrapbooks, Illustrations, and Photographs.

odd.head: Metadata Rights Declaration
odd.p: Finding aid description and metadata in this record are licensed under a Creative Commons Public Domain Designation (CC0 1.0 Universal). See LSC's Metadata Rights Statement for more information.

did.unittitle: Playbills
did.unitdate: circa 1762, 1786, 1790s, early 1800s-1865, 1871, early 1880s, 1895, early 1900s, and undated

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The series consists of 18th, 19th, and 20th century British theatre playbills. The bulk of series are playbills from the 19th century and include both color and black and white specimens. The playbills represent performances from Astley's Royal Amphitheatre; Lyceum Theatre; Nottingham Empire; Royal Princess's Theater; Surrey Theatre; Theatre Royal, Covent-Garden; Theatre Royal, Drury Lane; and other theatres. Additionally included is one Russian language playbill, one French language playbill, and four items representing Yiddish theatre that are printed in English and what appears to be Hebrew. Among the many performers represented are Edwin Booth, William Cooke, Mr. Ducrow, Charles Kean, Edward Kean, Mr. C. Kemble, Madame Vestris, and Mr. Young.

did.unittitle: Scrapbooks, Illustrations, and Photographs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series consists of five scrapbooks and loose illustrations and photographs. The scrapbooks represent 19th and early 20th century theatre. Two scrapbooks contain illustrations/caricatures and photographs; one scrapbook is primarily autographs; one scrapbook is cut outs from American theater playbills; and one scrapbook consists of cut out characters for toy theatre representing Robinson Cursoe, Black-eyed Susan, and Hamlet. The loose illustrations and photographs represent performers, theatres, and costumes. Additionally, included is one letter from Macready to Count D'Orsay.

did.unittitle: von Allers Circus illustrations (6 items)
Edwin Booth photographs (cabinet cards) (2 items)
Color Costume Plates (3 items)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Full Dress of a Gentleman; Half Dress; and Promenade Dress.

did.unittitle: Color Figures for Toy Theatres illustrations (3 items)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Pollock's New Panto Mime Characters; Redington's New Sixteens; and Skelt's New Demons.

did.unittitle: Mr. T. P. Cooke as Ben Backstay illustration
Mr. Creswich as Hamlet tuppence color illustration
Jumbo the Great Elephant and his keeper Scott chromolithographic poster

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Drawn from life by A.H. Wray.

did.unittitle: Mr. Kean illustration
Mr. Kean as Bajazet illustration
Charles Kean illustrations (7 items)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Photographs of illustrations representing A Midsummer's Night Dream and King John (1852 Feb). Illustration of Mr. Kean as Brutus and Richard the Third.

did.unittitle: Edmund Kean illustrations (original and printed) (6 items)
Mr. Kemble illustration
Macready letter to Count D'Orsay

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content

did.unittitle: Mr. Phelps and Miss Glyn illustration
Prints of theatres and actors (6 items)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Mr. C. Kemble as Falconbridge; Old Price Riots in Drury Lane; Mr. Phelps as Sir John Falstaff; The Rt. Hon.; The Earl of Barrymore and Capt. Wathen as Scrub and Archer; and The Singles.

did.unittitle: Scrapbook

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Inside cover annotated Emma F. [indecipherable last name] May 1877. Written over Wilfred Brandon's Collection. Cut out illustrations of Robinson Cursoe, Black-eyed Susan, and Hamlet. With printed sheet music titled Davidson's Little Songs for Little Singers Buttercups and Daisies and Davidson's Little Songs for Little Singers Farmer Went Trotting.

did.unittitle: Scrapbook

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: With pieces of playbills, letters, cut outs from daily advertisements, and autographs.

did.unittitle: Scrapbook

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Inside cover annotated Arthur Williams. Cut outs of photographs and caricatures of actors and/or actors in scenes. Some actors identified: George Barrett, Mr. J.B. Buckstone, Charles Mathews, and others.

did.unittitle: Scrapbook

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: American playbills. Front cover embossed with color illustration of dogs.

did.unittitle: Scrapbook

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Theater and concert programs and photographs of actors and/or actors in scenes.

did.unittitle: St. Stephen's Review Presentation Cartoon

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Coloured lithographic cartoon by Tom Merry. Caption reads: JUST A' GOIN' TO BEGIN! W. H. Smith (loq.) Walk up, gentlemen, walk up-no waiting, no loss of time! All in to begin!

did.unittitle: Tamburlaine the Great photographs on postcards (6 items)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Some actors identified: Jill Balcon, David Greene, Leo McKern, Lee Montague, Marget Rawlings, Reginald Tate, David Waller, and Donald Wolfit.
